headline: Netflix earnings: What to expect amid Warner Bros. bidding war
summary: Netflix (NFLX) is reportedly considering switching its Warner Bros. (WBD) acquisition offer to an all-cash bid. The headlines come days before the company's quarterly earnings release on Tuesday, Jan. 20. Manhattan Venture Partners head of research Santosh Rao joins Market Domination host Josh Lipton to discuss the upcoming earnings print in the context of the Warner Bros. bidding war. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

headline: Netflix Results to Shine Light on Fundamentals Amid Warner Fight
summary: Investors have been concerned about Netflix’s slowing flow of subscribers and the sustainability of its growth.  The issue sparked the worst selloff in the stock in more than three years after the company’s previous earnings report on Oct. 21.  At the time, Netflix was seen as a possible suitor for Warner Bros. Now that the deal is on the table at $82.7 billion, some investors are on edge and all the risks are amplified.

Now that the deal is on the table at $82.7 billion, some investors are on edge and all the risks are amplified.

headline: Netflix and Warner Bros. Discovery Amend Agreement to All-Cash Transaction
summary: Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ:NFLX) ("Netflix") and Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. ("WBD" or "Warner Bros. Discovery") announced they have amended their definitive agreement for Netflix's pending acquisition of Warner Bros. to an all-cash transaction. The revised agreement simplifies the transaction structure, provides greater certainty of value for WBD stockholders, and accelerates the path to a WBD stockholder vote.

content.title: Netflix and Warner Bros. Discovery Amend Agreement to All-Cash Transaction
content.summary: Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ:NFLX) ("Netflix") and Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. ("WBD" or "Warner Bros. Discovery") announced they have amended their definitive agreement for Netflix's pending acquisition of Warner Bros. to an all-cash transaction. The revised agreement simplifies the transaction structure, provides greater certainty of value for WBD stockholders, and accelerates the path to a WBD stockholder vote.

headline: Netflix revises its offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to make it an all-cash transaction
summary: Netflix is revising its $72 billion offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to make it an all-cash transaction.  Netflix initially put forth a cash and stock deal valued at $27.75 per Warner Bros. share, giving it a total enterprise value of $82.7 billion, including debt.  Netflix and Warner Bros. said Tuesday that the revised deal simplifies the transaction structure, provides more certainty of value for Warner Bros. stockholders and speeds up the path to a Warner Bros. shareholder vote.

content.title: Netflix revises its offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to make it an all-cash transaction
content.summary: Netflix is revising its $72 billion offer for Warner Bros. Discovery to make it an all-cash transaction.  Netflix initially put forth a cash and stock deal valued at $27.75 per Warner Bros. share, giving it a total enterprise value of $82.7 billion, including debt.  Netflix and Warner Bros. said Tuesday that the revised deal simplifies the transaction structure, provides more certainty of value for Warner Bros. stockholders and speeds up the path to a Warner Bros. shareholder vote.

headline: Warner Strikes New All-Cash Deal With Netflix
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery  and  Netflix  said Tuesday they struck a new all-cash deal for Netflix to buy Warner’s studios and HBO Max streaming business.  Warner also released financial details on the cable-networks business it plans to spin off.  The all-cash deal of $27.75 per share replaces Netflix’s previous cash-and-stock deal.

content.title: Warner Strikes New All-Cash Deal With Netflix
content.summary: Warner Bros. Discovery  and  Netflix  said Tuesday they struck a new all-cash deal for Netflix to buy Warner’s studios and HBO Max streaming business.  Warner also released financial details on the cable-networks business it plans to spin off.  The all-cash deal of $27.75 per share replaces Netflix’s previous cash-and-stock deal.

headline: Could Netflix Stumble?
summary: The most valuable media company of all time reports full-year results this afternoon.  Now it isn’t even close:  Netflix  is bigger than every one of its old-school Hollywood competitors combined.  Netflix’s stock is up 27,000% since it launched streaming, and the company has balanced rapid growth and solid profitability: Return on invested capital and free cash flow conversion are both impressive.

headline: Netflix will now pay all cash for Warner Bros to keep Paramount at bay
summary:
STORY: Netflix switched to an all-cash offer for Warner Bros Discovery's studio and streaming assets on Tuesday (January 20).

But it didn't increase its $82.7 billion bid.

The streaming giant wants to beat Paramount's rival efforts to buy the Hollywood giant.

According to a regulatory filing, the new all-cash bid - at $27.75 a share - has unanimous support from the HBO owner's board.

Both Netflix and Paramount Skydance want Warner Bros for its leading film and television studios, extensive content library and major franchises.

These include "Game of Thrones," "Harry Potter" and DC Comics' superheroes "Batman" and "Superman."

Paramount has changed its terms and engaged in an aggressive media campaign to try to convince shareholders its bid is superior.

But Warner Bros has so far rejected the David Ellison-led company.

Shares of Netflix, which is slated to report quarterly earnings after the market close, were up more than 1% before the bell.

Though they have fallen almost 15% since announcing the merger in early December.

That drop was part of Paramount's argument that its bid was superior.

Warner Bros rejected the Paramount bid as it argued its all-cash offer was insufficient after factoring in risks, costs and uncertainties.

content.title: Netflix will now pay all cash for Warner Bros to keep Paramount at bay
content.summary:
STORY: Netflix switched to an all-cash offer for Warner Bros Discovery's studio and streaming assets on Tuesday (January 20).

But it didn't increase its $82.7 billion bid.

The streaming giant wants to beat Paramount's rival efforts to buy the Hollywood giant.

According to a regulatory filing, the new all-cash bid - at $27.75 a share - has unanimous support from the HBO owner's board.

Both Netflix and Paramount Skydance want Warner Bros for its leading film and television studios, extensive content library and major franchises.

These include "Game of Thrones," "Harry Potter" and DC Comics' superheroes "Batman" and "Superman."

Paramount has changed its terms and engaged in an aggressive media campaign to try to convince shareholders its bid is superior.

But Warner Bros has so far rejected the David Ellison-led company.

Shares of Netflix, which is slated to report quarterly earnings after the market close, were up more than 1% before the bell.

Though they have fallen almost 15% since announcing the merger in early December.

That drop was part of Paramount's argument that its bid was superior.

Warner Bros rejected the Paramount bid as it argued its all-cash offer was insufficient after factoring in risks, costs and uncertainties.

headline: Spencer Jakab | Could Netflix Stumble? Stranger Things Have Happened.
summary: 27,000% That's how much Netflix stock is up since it launched video streaming, helping turn it into the world's most valuable media company of all time. In the latest edition of my Markets A.M. newsletter, I look at how defensible Netflix's "moat" is, and consider one potential threat—YouTube's hugely popular crowdsourced content, which is pretty hard to compete with on volume and price.

headline: Netflix intensifies bid for Warner Bros making its $72 billion offer all cash
summary: Netflix is now offering to buy Warner Bros. Discovery’s studio and streaming business in all cash — in an effort to win over the Hollywood giant's shareholders for its $72 billion merger and potentially thwart a hostile bid from Skydance-owned Paramount.  Back in December, Netflix struck a cash and stock deal with Warner valued at $27.75 per share, giving it a total enterprise value of $82.7 billion, including debt.  Warner stockholders will also receive the additional value of shares of Discovery Global, which would become a separate public company following a previously-announced separation from Warner Bros.

content.title: Netflix intensifies bid for Warner Bros making its $72 billion offer all cash
content.summary: Netflix is now offering to buy Warner Bros. Discovery’s studio and streaming business in all cash — in an effort to win over the Hollywood giant's shareholders for its $72 billion merger and potentially thwart a hostile bid from Skydance-owned Paramount.  Back in December, Netflix struck a cash and stock deal with Warner valued at $27.75 per share, giving it a total enterprise value of $82.7 billion, including debt.  Warner stockholders will also receive the additional value of shares of Discovery Global, which would become a separate public company following a previously-announced separation from Warner Bros.

headline: Netflix boosts offer for Warner Bros Discovery
summary: Netflix has boosted its offer for media giant Warner Bros Discovery (WBD) as it seeks to fend off a hostile takeover from entertainment conglomerate Paramount.  The streaming giant is now offering to pay cash, not just Netflix shares, in an attempt to improve the attractiveness of its offer.  The total value of the deal, $82.7bn (£61.4bn), is unchanged, but now shareholders will receive cash rather than a part ownership of Netflix.

content.title: Netflix boosts offer for Warner Bros Discovery
content.summary: Netflix has boosted its offer for media giant Warner Bros Discovery (WBD) as it seeks to fend off a hostile takeover from entertainment conglomerate Paramount.  The streaming giant is now offering to pay cash, not just Netflix shares, in an attempt to improve the attractiveness of its offer.  The total value of the deal, $82.7bn (£61.4bn), is unchanged, but now shareholders will receive cash rather than a part ownership of Netflix.

Discovery (WBD), and OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) and ServiceNow (NOW). They also look at 3M (MMM), which reported earnings. Watch the video above to learn why investors are focused on the three tickers. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

Watch the video above to learn why investors are focused on the three tickers.

headline: Netflix Revises Warner Bros. Bid to All-Cash as Paramount Pressure Builds
summary: Netflix amends its $27.75-a-share offer to all cash, accelerating a shareholder vote amid Paramount's $30-a-share tender offer.

headline: Netflix revises offer to pay all cash for Warner Bros. to fend off Paramount
summary: However, the streaming giant is still offering the same $27.75 the companies had agreed on for WBD's movie studio and streaming assets, and the deal continues to value the company at $82.7 billion.

content.title: Netflix revises offer to pay all cash for Warner Bros. to fend off Paramount
content.summary: However, the streaming giant is still offering the same $27.75 the companies had agreed on for WBD's movie studio and streaming assets, and the deal continues to value the company at $82.7 billion.

headline: Netflix Stock Falls After Video Streamer Misses With Q1 Outlook

headline: Netflix slightly beats revenue estimates as subscribers reach 325 million
summary: Netflix narrowly exceeded Wall Street's revenue estimates for its holiday quarter, as viewers tuned in for the final season of ​the hit sci-fi series "Stranger Things," sending its shares down 4% in after-hours trading.  The company ‌forecast annual revenue for 2026 modestly ahead of analyst expectations, even as Netflix surpassed 325 million subscribers globally.  Nielsen reported that Netflix's monthly viewership rose 10% in December, thanks largely to the final season of hit sci-fi series "Stranger Things," which generated 15 billion viewing minutes.

content.title: Netflix slightly beats revenue estimates as subscribers reach 325 million
content.summary: Netflix narrowly exceeded Wall Street's revenue estimates for its holiday quarter, as viewers tuned in for the final season of ​the hit sci-fi series "Stranger Things," sending its shares down 4% in after-hours trading.  The company ‌forecast annual revenue for 2026 modestly ahead of analyst expectations, even as Netflix surpassed 325 million subscribers globally.  Nielsen reported that Netflix's monthly viewership rose 10% in December, thanks largely to the final season of hit sci-fi series "Stranger Things," which generated 15 billion viewing minutes.

headline: Tech Earnings Are Here. Capex, Memory Prices, and Software’s Future Will Be Key Themes.
summary: Wall Street is keeping an eye on several themes this tech earnings season that stand out from the past.  A major theme impacting tech hardware companies is the rising cost of memory.  Memory demand is outpacing supply as the need for memory that powers artificial intelligence increases.

content.title: Tech Earnings Are Here. Capex, Memory Prices, and Software’s Future Will Be Key Themes.
content.summary: Wall Street is keeping an eye on several themes this tech earnings season that stand out from the past.  A major theme impacting tech hardware companies is the rising cost of memory.  Memory demand is outpacing supply as the need for memory that powers artificial intelligence increases.
